p.s: Racism in Germany
How do African-Americans living in Germany experience racism?
To be more precise, how does Jérôme Boateng feel about racism in Germany?
That is the question I want to discuss today.
This is actually my first blog entry on here so I would just like to quickly introduce myself.
My name is Jane and I am currently volunteering for an international cultural exchange.
I am originally from Germany so it's quite exciting for me to be in the USA right now.
I recently found an article where Jérôme Boateng talks about his experience playing soccer as an African-American in Germany which is quite fitting for this blog entry.

Jérôme Boateng states that there were multiple insidencensincidents where he experienced racism in Germany, people used racial slurs against him, spit on him, made monkey noises when he was warming up for a game.
Even when he was younger, maybe around ten, parents from the opposite team called him names, racial slurs, the n-word and so on, sometimes, he shares in the interview, he even cried.
He explains that his parents never talked about racism and discrimination against African people or people with a different skin colour until someone called him the n-word.
He explains that for him as a child, he really couldn't understand why someone would have a problem with his skin colour.
Jérôme Boateng also talks about the German society in general in an interview with Herbert Grönemeyer, a German singer and songwriter.
Here he says that the refugees crisis is actually a big topic in Germany right now, one he also talks a lot about with his family and friends.
Jérôme Boateng adds that the country is struggling with itself and that always the same questions aren't answered, e.g. what happens with everyone coming here? and how will that change our life?.
Moreover he adds that the society itself is more open and has more diversity.
He states that the big win for Germany in the WMWeltmeisterschaft 2014 (European soccer contest) wouldn't have been possible without the colourful and diverse team they had.
Nevertheless he adds, that more and more people have prejudice against people of colour, people who weren't born here or people who'swhose parents weren't born here.
This article was published in Jérôme Boateng's first magazine Boa, in case you want to look it up.
Personally I can totally agree with him.
Our society in Germany is getting more and more diverse.
But through that the hatred also grows.
Especially as a public and famous person of colour, you don't have an easy life.
This is why it's especially important to raise attention to this topic and not just sit down and watch it happening!
I hope you all enjoyed this blog post, even if the topic is not joyful at all...
